header_summary:
Maxim Orlovsky announces the stable release of the RGB project's consensus layer, RGB-I-0, after extensive development, emphasizing its significance in client-side validation technology and the integration of zk-STARK support to enhance protocol functionality. The release is a key milestone in the project's history, marking the beginning of forward compatibility for developers and contract issuers, with an anticipation of further releases focusing on libraries to maintain contract compatibility. Detailed information about the release and its features can be found in the [official announcement](https://rgb.tech/blog/release-v0-12-consensus/).

Aaron Zhang explores the practical application of Taproot mechanisms within Bitcoin, demonstrating the construction of a Taproot address with multiple spending paths and providing a byte-by-byte analysis of control blocks. His work, which includes detailed examinations and practical demonstrations on the Bitcoin testnet, serves as an educational resource for developers interested in advanced Bitcoin scripting capabilities. Zhang's analysis and resources are available through his Medium posts ([Part 1](https://medium.com/@aaron.recompile/building-a-4-leaf-taproot-tree-in-python-the-first-complete-implementation-on-bitcoin-testnet-c8b66c331f29), [Part 2](https://medium.com/@aaron.recompile/taproot-control-block-deep-analysis-stack-execution-visualization-5ff10f98032c)), and a [GitHub repository](https://github.com/btcstudy/btcstudy.github.io/tree/main/Not-Just-Hodling:bitcoin-script-Engineering/demo3_taproot_4leaf).

Jonas Nick discusses the security considerations of using WOTS+ over WOTS in Bitcoin development, highlighting the potential security reduction with RMD160 and the implications of quantum computing on cryptographic security. This discussion underscores the importance of selecting hash algorithms that balance security and efficiency in the face of advancing quantum computing technologies, with further details available in the provided [contextual discussion](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/h9N4uIp0MgaASuEBpqsHjiQb9ahGbca3mG5V6iPVumT9ICT4monwV1ScgV3kdV2ka9CkQiSqEGkxA_eqqGQJ1TtFmWUlJEhi0McZU6yGBl0=@proton.me/T/#m5143408c20ebdb01c0f7983048d968b88a8f6762).

The LNP/BP Standards Association launches the final production-ready release of the RGB smart contracts consensus layer, version 0.12, highlighting significant protocol simplifications and advancements in payment processes, performance, and security. This release marks a pivotal moment for contract developers and the future of smart contracts on the Bitcoin mainnet, with resources and further information available on [GitHub](https://github.com/RGB-WG/rgb/tree/v0.12.0-rc.1.1).

recent_posts.title: RGB consensus layer released for production deployments
recent_posts.summary:
- After years of work, the RGB project released its stable consensus layer, RGB-I-0.
- The release, enhancing with zk-STARK support, marks a key advancement in client-side validation.
- This milestone ensures contracts are forward-compatible, highlighting the project's innovation and community effort.

recent_posts.title: [taproot][script] 4-leaf Taproot Merkle Tree in Python: testnet implementation + control block analysis
recent_posts.summary:
- Aaron Zhang shared his project on Bitcoin's Taproot mechanisms, featuring a 4-leaf Taproot Merkle tree.
- His work includes detailed analyses and testnet demonstrations of various Taproot transaction validations.
- Zhang provides resources and encourages discussion on Taproot's application, aiming to enhance Bitcoin scripting skills.

recent_posts.title: OP_CAT Enables Winternitz Signatures
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion evaluates WOTS+ versus WOTS for Bitcoin, focusing on hash algorithm choices.
- Shift to RMD160 in WOTS+ could reduce security level due to lower collision resistance.
- Incorporating OP_HASH160 might preserve SHA256's resistance but still poses security risks.

recent_posts.title: RGB consensus production release v0.12
recent_posts.summary:
- The LNP/BP Standards Association launched RGB smart contracts version 0.12 for Bitcoin.
- Version 0.12 introduces zk-AluVM, improving protocol performance and security.
- Future updates will focus on integrating RGB v.0.12 into products by Summer 2025.

active_posts.title: Unbreaking testnet4
active_posts.summary:
- Testnet4's difficulty reset rule aims to make block mining on laptops easier but has issues.
- A scheduled hard fork on January 1, 2026, will remove this rule to improve Testnet4.
- This change strives to balance simulation accuracy with developer accessibility in testing.

active_posts.title: What's a good stopping point? Making the case for the capabilities enabled by CTV+CSFS
active_posts.summary:
- Discussions on a proposed Bitcoin soft fork focus on introducing OP_CTV and OP_TXHASH.
- Alternatives like maintaining status quo and validation rollups are being considered.
- Proponents argue the soft fork balances simplicity with significant improvements to existing protocols.

active_posts.title: A Taproot-native (re-)bindable transaction bundle proposal
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine Poinsot, Steven Roose, and Greg Sanders proposed a Bitcoin technical enhancement.
- Their proposal introduces "OP_TEMPLATEHASH", improving Bitcoin through simplicity and efficiency.
- The initiative includes detailed documentation and draws inspiration from "LNHANCE" for opcode discussions.

active_posts.title: Correcting the error in getnetworkhashrateps
active_posts.summary:
- The current method overestimates network hash rate, needing correction for accuracy.
- A proposed correction involves adjusting calculation by multiplying by (N-1)/N.
- Another improvement suggests counting blocks over a fixed time to apply Poisson statistics.

active_posts.title: Understanding and Mitigating a OP_CTV Footgun: The Unsatisfiable UTXO
active_posts.summary:
- `OP_CTV` in Bitcoin scripting aims to manage transaction inputs effectively.
- Incorporating multiple inputs into `OP_CTV` templates helps avoid unspendable UTXOs.
- Ongoing research enhances `OP_CTV` applications, ensuring secure, efficient transactions.

active_posts.title: Reimagining Onion Messages as an Overlay Layer
active_posts.summary:
- Reimagining onion messaging in LN as an overlay improves speed, privacy, and efficiency.
- Overlay layering decreases necessary hops, enhancing payment experience and privacy through key rotation.
- Implementation involves LN gossip network bootstrapping and secure TLV-based handshake messages.

today_in_history_posts.title: Covenant opcode proposal OP_CONSTRAINDESTINATION (an alternative to OP_CTV)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A new opcode, OP_CONSTRAINDESTINATION, aims to restrict output destinations in covenant scripts.
- It allows specifying addresses and constraining output's fee contributions, enhancing wallet vault flexibility.
- Feedback for the OP_CONSTRAINDESTINATION proposal, available on Github, is encouraged to refine it further.

today_in_history_posts.title: Impact of eltoo loss of state
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Alice and Carol risk losing funds due to Bob's outdated backup and channel state update.
- Carol can facilitate refunds by allowing Bob the first claim, promoting cooperative closings.
- Strategies include real-time state indexing and limiting inbound PTLC value to manage risks.

today_in_history_posts.title: Bolt 12 Trusted Contacts
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bolt 12 enhances lightning wallets, allowing payments with metadata and contacts without sharing invoices.
- It proposes a selective identity revelation method via contact key distribution and mutual authentication.
- Seeking developer feedback to refine the process for secure, private transactions with known contacts.
